        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/py2to3/portfolio.py:cointegration' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/py2to3/portfolio.py#L639'>cointegration</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>x,<br>y,<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>  """ Output :
<br>
    coint_t :t-statistic of unit-root test on residuals
<br>
    pvalue :   MacKinnon's approximate p-value based on MacKinnon (1994)
<br>
    crit_value : Critical values for the test statistic at the 1 %, 5 %, and 10 %  Signifiance levels.
<br>

<br>
    The Null hypothesis is that there is no cointegration, the alt hypothesis is that there is cointegrating relationship. 
<br>
    If the pvalue is small, below a critical size:  Reject Null Hypothesis -->  Cointegration
<br>
           pvalue is high --> No Cointegration    
<br>
    
<br>
    Significance level, also denoted as alpha or α, is the probability of rejecting  the null hypothesis when it is true.
<br>
    Probability of incorrectly rejecting a true null hypothesis
<br>

<br>
    P=0.05  , At least 23% (and typically close to 50%)
<br>
    P=0.01  , At least 7% (and typically close to 15%
<br>

<br>
    (-2.9607012342275936,
<br>
    0.038730981052330332, 0,
<br>
    249,
<br>
    {'1%': -3.4568881317725864,
<br>
       '10%': -2.5729936189738876,
<br>
     '5%': -2.8732185133016057},
<br>
      601.96849256295991)
<br>
        It can be seen that the calculated test statistic of -2.96 is smaller than the 5% critical value of -2.87, 
<br>
        which means that we can reject the null hypothesis that  there isn't a cointegrating relationship at the 5% level.
<br>
  """
<br>
</li>
        </ul>
    </details>

def imp_yahoo_periodic_figure(soup, yahoo_figure):
<br>
    values = []; pattern = re.compile(yahoo_figure)
<br>

<br>
    title = soup.find("strong", text=pattern)    # works for the figures printed in bold
<br>
    if title:  row = title.parent.parent
<br>
    else:
<br>
        title = soup.find("td", text=pattern)    # works for any other available figure
<br>
        if title:  row = title.parent
<br>
        else:      sys.exit("Invalid figure '" + yahoo_figure + "' passed.")
<br>

<br>
    cells = row.find_all("td")[1:]    # exclude the <td> with figure name
<br>
    for cell in cells:
<br>
        if cell.text.strip() != yahoo_figure:    # needed because some figures are indented
<br>
            str_value = cell.text.strip().replace(",", "").replace("(", "-").replace(")", "")
<br>
            if str_value == "-": str_value = 0
<br>
            value = int(str_value) * 1000
<br>
            values.append(value)
<br>

<br>
    return values
<br>

def imp_googleIntradayQuote(symbol, freqsec=300, nday=5):
<br>
    ''' Intraday quotes from google. Specify interval seconds and number of days
<br>
    http://www.google.com/finance/getprices?q=7261&i=300&p=3d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v
<br>
    '''
<br>
    url ="http://www.google.com/finance/getprices?q={0}".format(symbol)
<br>
    url +="&i={0}&p={1}d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v".format(freqsec, nday)
<br>
    try :      
<br>
       resp= requests.post(url)
<br>
       csv= resp.text
<br>
       csv= csv.splitlines()
<br>
    except :
<br>
       print('Err Intaday '+symbol)
<br>

<br>
    if len(csv) < 9 :
<br>
      print 'Using Daily',
<br>

<br>
      url='http://www.google.com/finance/historical?q='+symbol+'&i='+str(freqsec)+'&p=3d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v&output=csv'
<br>
      csv = urllib.urlopen(url).readlines()
<br>
      csv.reverse()
<br>
      q=[]
<br>
      for bar in xrange(0,len(csv)-1):
<br>
        ds,open_,high,low,close,volume = csv[bar].rstrip().split(',')
<br>
        if isfloat(open_) and isfloat(high) :
<br>
          open_,high,low,close = [float(x) for x in [open_,high,low,close]]
<br>
          dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds,'%d-%b-%y')
<br>
          q.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
      df= util.pd_array_todataframe(q, ['date','open','high','low','close','volume'])
<br>
      return df
<br>

<br>

<br>
    # print(csv)
<br>
    qq=[]
<br>
    for bar in xrange(7,len(csv)):
<br>
      if csv[bar].count(',')!=5: continue
<br>
      offset,close,high,low,open_,volume = csv[bar].split(',')
<br>
      
<br>
      if offset[0]=='a':
<br>
        day = float(offset[1:])
<br>
        offset = 0
<br>
      else:
<br>
        offset = float(offset)
<br>
      open_, high, low, close = [float(x) for x in [open_,high,low,close]]
<br>
      dt = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(day + (freqsec * offset))
<br>
      #print (dt,open_,high,low,close,volume)
<br>
      qq.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
    df= util.pd_array_todataframe(qq, ['date','open','high','low','close','volume'])
<br>
    return df

    url +="&startdate={0}&enddate={1}&output=csv".format( start.strftime('%b %d, %Y'),end.strftime('%b %d, %Y'))

    csv = urllib.urlopen(url).readlines()
<br>
    csv.reverse()

    q=[]

    for bar in xrange(0,len(csv)-1):

class Quote(object):
<br>
  DATE_FMT = '%Y-%m-%d';  TIME_FMT = '%H:%M:%S'
<br>

<br>
  def __init__(self):
<br>
    self.symbol = '';    self.exchn=''
<br>
    self.date,self.time,self.open_,self.high,self.low,self.close,self.volume = ([] for _ in range(7))
<br>

<br>
  def append(self,dt,open_,high,low,close,volume):
<br>
    self.date.append(dt.date())
<br>
    self.time.append(dt.time())
<br>
    self.open_.append(float(open_))
<br>
    self.high.append(float(high))
<br>
    self.low.append(float(low))
<br>
    self.close.append(float(close))
<br>
    self.volume.append(int(volume))
<br>

<br>
  def to_csv(self):
<br>
    return ''.join(["{0},{1},{2},{3:.2f},{4:.2f},{5:.2f},{6:.2f},{7}\n".format(self.symbol,
<br>
              self.date[bar].strftime('%Y-%m-%d'),self.time[bar].strftime('%H:%M:%S'),
<br>
              self.open_[bar],self.high[bar],self.low[bar],self.close[bar],self.volume[bar])
<br>
              for bar in xrange(len(self.close))])
<br>

<br>
  def write_csv(self,filename):
<br>
    with open(filename,'w') as f:
<br>
      txt= self.to_csv()
<br>
      f.write(txt)
<br>

<br>
  def read_csv(self,filename):
<br>
    self.symbol = ''
<br>
    self.date,self.time,self.open_,self.high,self.low,self.close,self.volume = ([] for _ in range(7))
<br>
    for line in open(filename,'r'):
<br>
      symbol,ds,ts,open_,high,low,close,volume = line.rstrip().split(',')
<br>
      self.symbol = symbol
<br>
      dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds+' '+ts,self.DATE_FMT+' '+self.TIME_FMT)
<br>
      self.append(dt,open_,high,low,close,volume)
<br>
    return True
<br>

<br>
  def __repr__(self):
<br>
    return self.to_csv()
<br>

<br>
#####################################################################################
<br>
#---------Run over all the indexes, with time lag -----------------------------------
<br>
def np_similarity(x,y, wwerr=[], type1=0):
<br>
  if type1==2 : return np_distance_l1(x,y, wwerr)
<br>
  if type1==1: return sci.spatial.distance.correlation(x, y)  
<br>
  if type1==0 : return 1-np.corrcoef(x,y)[0,1]
<br>

<br>
def np_distance_l1(x,y, wwerr) :
<br>
 return np.sum(wwerr * np.abs(x-y))  
<br>
  
<br>
#---------------------  Universe Load         ---------------------------------------
<br>
filejpstock= r'E:/_data/stock/daily/20160616/jp'
<br>
sym01= nk400list
<br>

<br>
quotes= imp_txt_getquotes(sym01, filejpstock, startdate=20090101, endate=20160616)
<br>
open1, dateref= date_align(quotes, type1="close")    #Get the data and align dates
<br>
del quotes; util.a_cleanmemory()
<br>

<br>
#util.save_obj(open1, 'close_nk400_2009_2016')
<br>
#util.save_obj(dateref, 'dateref_nk400_2009_2016')
<br>

<br>
open1= util.load_obj('close_nk400_2009_2016')
<br>
dateref= util.load_obj( 'dateref_nk400_2009_2016')
<br>

<br>
nlag=1
<br>
ret_open1 =  getdailyret_fromquotes(open1,nlag)
<br>
del open1
<br>

<br>
#--------------------  Search Asset Input     ---------------------------------------
<br>
name1= '7203' 
<br>
date1= 20160328
<br>
date2= 20160531
<br>
twindow= util.np_findfirst(date2, dateref) - util.np_findfirst(date1, dateref) 
<br>

<br>

<br>
tstartx= util.np_findfirst(date1, dateref)          # Date Index
<br>
stockx= util.np_findfirst(name1, sym01)
<br>
retx= ret_open1[stockx, tstartx:(tstartx+twindow-1)]    # Recent Period
<br>
px= price_normalize_1d(retx)
<br>
nx= len(px)
<br>

<br>

<br>
#----OverWeight for Local Min, Local Max         -----------------------------------
<br>
wwerr= np.ones(nx, dtype=np.float16)
<br>
vvmax= util.np_findlocalmax(px); xprev=0
<br>
for x in vvmax:
<br>
  if x[0] !=0 and np.abs(xprev-x[0]) > 6: 
<br>
    wwerr[max(0,x[0]-1):min(nx,(x[0]+1))]= 1.5;    xprev= x[0] 
<br>

<br>
vvmin= util.np_findlocalmin(px); xprev=0
<br>
for x in vvmin:
<br>
  if x[0] !=0 and np.abs(xprev-x[0]) > 6: 
<br>
    wwerr[max(0,x[0]-1):min(nx,(x[0]+1))]= 1.5;    xprev= x[0] 
<br>

<br>

<br>
#--------------------  Search the Pattern       -------------------------------------
<br>
tmaxx= len(dateref)-1
<br>
similar_list= np.zeros((nstock*(tmaxx-twindow)+1, 3), np.float16)
<br>
i=0
<br>
for iy in range(0, nstock) :
<br>
 for t in range(0, tmaxx-twindow):
<br>
   if iy == stockx and t > tstartx : 
<br>
     pass
<br>
   else :
<br>
    rety= ret_open1[iy, t:(t+twindow-1)]
<br>
    py=   price_normalize_1d(rety)
<br>
    ss= np_similarity(px, py, wwerr=wwerr, type1=2)
<br>
    i+=1
<br>
    similar_list[i,0]= iy
<br>
    similar_list[i,1]= t
<br>
    similar_list[i,2]= ss
<br>

<br>

<br>
 #-------------------Clean the table -------------------------------------------------
<br>
rank= util.np_sortbycolumn(similar_list,2, asc=True)
<br>
for i,x in enumerate(rank) :
<br>
  if rank[i,2]==0.0 : rank[i,2]= 1000         # Empty cell
<br>
  if rank[i,1]> tstartx-3 : rank[i,2]= 100    # Start Element
<br>
rank= util.np_sortbycolumn(rank,2, asc=True)  
<br>

<br>

<br>
 #----- Show Similar Stocks ---------------------------------------------------------
<br>
show_only_different_time= True
<br>

<br>
for i in range(0,10) :
<br>
 tstarti= rank[i,1]
<br>
 stocki= int(rank[i,0])
<br>
 
<br>
 if show_only_different_time and tstarti < tstartx-1  :
<br>
   py= price_normalize100(ret_open1[stocki, tstarti:(tstarti+twindow-1)]) 
<br>

<br>
   namei= sym01[stocki]
<br>
   namefulli= nk400name[util.np_findfirst(namei, nk400list)]
<br>

<br>
   tit= namei+ " " +namefulli+ " " + str(dateref[tstarti])          
<br>
   plot_price(px-100, py-100, label=('Similar '+tit, 'Time','% Var') )
<br>

<br>

<br>
kix= util.np_findfirst(name1, statsjp[:,0, ilag])
<br>
stocklist01[390]
<br>

<br>

<br>
stocklist01[157] , nk400name[157] ,  dateref1adj[86]     
<br>
plot_price(price_normalize100(ret_open1[157, 86:86+twindow-1])-100,px-100   )
<br>
'''    
<br>

    <details>
        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zzarchive/zutil.py:os_print_tofile' href='.//utilmy/zzarchive/zutil.py#L808'>os_print_tofile</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>vv,<br>file1,<br>mode1 = "a",<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>    """
<br>
    Here is a list of the different modes of opening a file:
<br>
r
<br>
Opens a file for reading only. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file.
<br>
This is the default mode.
<br>

<br>
rb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for reading only in binary format. The file pointer is placed at the
<br>
beginning of the file. This is the default mode.
<br>
r+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file.
<br>
rb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing in binary format. The file pointer will be at the
<br>
beginning of the file.
<br>
w
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist,
<br>
creates a new file for writing.
<br>
wb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only in binary format. Overwrites the file if the file exists.
<br>
If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing.
<br>
w+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists.
<br>
If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
wb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading in binary format. Overwrites the existing file if
<br>
the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
a
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is,
<br>
the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing.
<br>
ab
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file
<br>
exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file
<br>
for writing.
<br>
a+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the
<br>
file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file
<br>
for reading and writing.
<br>
ab+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of
<br>
the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist,
<br>
it creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
To open a text file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "r")
<br>

<br>
To read a text file, use:
<br>
print fh.read()
<br>

<br>
To read one line at a time, use:
<br>
print fh.readline()
<br>

<br>
To read a list of lines use:
<br>
print fh.readlines()
<br>

<br>
To write to a file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "w")
<br>
lines_of_text = ["a line of text", "another line of text", "a third line"]
<br>
fh.writelines(lines_of_text)
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
To append to file, use:
<br>
fh = open("Hello.txt", "a")
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
    """
<br>
</li>

<br>

<br>
# Get the xlsxwriter objects from the dataframe writer object.
<br>
workbook  = writer.book
<br>
worksheet = writer.sheets['Sheet1']
<br>

<br>
# Add some cell formats.
<br>
format1 = workbook.add_format({'num_format': '#,##0.00'})
<br>
format2 = workbook.add_format({'num_format': '0%'})
<br>
format3 = workbook.add_format({'num_format': 'h:mm:ss AM/PM'})
<br>

<br>
# Set the column width and format.
<br>
worksheet.set_column('B:B', 18, format1)
<br>

<br>
# Set the format but not the column width.
<br>
worksheet.set_column('C:C', None, format2)
<br>

<br>
worksheet.set_column('D:D', 16, format3)
<br>

<br>
# Close the Pandas Excel writer and output the Excel file.
<br>
writer.save()
<br>

<br>

<br>
wb = load_workbook(outfile)
<br>
ws = wb.active
<br>
ws.title = 'Table 1'
<br>

<br>
tableshape = np.shape(table)
<br>
alph = list(string.ascii_uppercase)
<br>

<br>
for i in range(tableshape[0]):
<br>
    for j in range(tableshape[1]):
<br>
        ws[alph[i]+str(j+1)] = table[i, j]
<br>

<br>
for cell in ws['A'] + ws[1]:
<br>
    cell.style = 'Pandas'
<br>

<br>
wb.save('Scores.xlsx')
<br>

<br>
   """

<br>

<br>
    newList = pivot(listOfDicts, ('Name',), ('Year',), 'Value')
<br>

<br>
    """

<br>
from pandas.tseries.holiday import USFederalHolidayCalendar
<br>
cal = USFederalHolidayCalendar()
<br>
holidays = cal.holidays('2012', '2016', return_name=True)
<br>
holidays.head()
<br>

<br>
holidays_all = pd.concat([holidays, "Day Before " + holidays.shift(-1, 'D'),  "Day After "
<br>
+ holidays.shift(1, 'D')])
<br>
holidays_all = holidays_all.sort_index()
<br>
holidays_all.head()
<br>

<br>
from pandas.tseries.offsets import CustomBusinessDay
<br>
from pandas.tseries.holiday import USFederalHolidayCalendar
<br>
bday_us = CustomBusinessDay(calendar=USFederalHolidayCalendar())
<br>
dateref[-1] - bday_us- bday_us
<br>

<br>
   """
<br>

<details>
<summary>
<a name='utilmy/zarchive/rstatpy.py' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/rstatpy.py'>utilmy/zarchive/rstatpy.py</a>
</summary>
<ul>
    <details>
        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/rstatpy.py:stl' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/rstatpy.py#L9'>stl</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>data,<br>ns,<br>np = None,<br>nt = None,<br>nl = None,<br>isdeg = 0,<br>itdeg = 1,<br>ildeg = 1,<br>nsjump = None,<br>ntjump = None,<br>nljump = None,<br>ni = 2,<br>no = 0,<br>fulloutput = False,<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>    """
<br>
    Seasonal-Trend decomposition procedure based on LOESS
<br>
    data : pandas.Series
<br>
    ns : int
<br>
        Length of the seasonal smoother.
<br>
        The value of  ns should be an odd integer greater than or equal to 3.
<br>
        A value ns>6 is recommended. As ns  increases  the  values  of  the
<br>
        seasonal component at a given point in the seasonal cycle (e.g., January
<br>
        values of a monthly series with  a  yearly cycle) become smoother.
<br>
    np : int
<br>
        Period of the seasonal component.
<br>
        For example, if  the  time series is monthly with a yearly cycle, then
<br>
        np=12.
<br>
        If no value is given, then the period will be determined from the
<br>
        ``data`` timeseries.
<br>
    nt : int
<br>
        Length of the trend smoother.
<br>
        The  value  of  nt should be an odd integer greater than or equal to 3.
<br>
        A value of nt between 1.5*np and 2*np is  recommended. As nt increases,
<br>
        the values of the trend component become  smoother.
<br>
        If nt is None, it is estimated as the smallest odd integer greater
<br>
        or equal to ``(1.5*np)/[1-(1.5/ns)]``
<br>
    nl : int
<br>
        Length of the low-pass filter.
<br>
        The value of nl should  be an odd integer greater than or equal to 3.
<br>
        The smallest odd integer greater than or equal to np is used by default.
<br>
    isdeg : int
<br>
        Degree of locally-fitted polynomial in seasonal smoothing.
<br>
        The value is 0 or 1.
<br>
    itdeg : int
<br>
        Degree of locally-fitted polynomial in trend smoothing.
<br>
        The value is 0 or 1.
<br>
    ildeg : int
<br>
        Degree of locally-fitted polynomial in low-pass smoothing.
<br>
        The value is 0 or 1.
<br>
    nsjump : int
<br>
        Skipping value for seasonal smoothing.
<br>
        The seasonal smoother skips ahead nsjump points and then linearly
<br>
        interpolates in between.  The value  of nsjump should be a positive
<br>
        integer; if nsjump=1, a seasonal smooth is calculated at all n points.
<br>
        To make the procedure run faster, a reasonable choice for nsjump is
<br>
        10%-20% of ns. By default, nsjump= 0.1*ns.
<br>
    ntjump : int
<br>
        Skipping value for trend smoothing. If None, ntjump= 0.1*nt
<br>
    nljump : int
<br>
        Skipping value for low-pass smoothing. If None, nljump= 0.1*nl
<br>
    ni :int
<br>
        Number of loops for updating the seasonal and trend  components.
<br>
        The value of ni should be a positive integer.
<br>
        See the next argument for advice on the  choice of ni.
<br>
        If ni is None, ni is set to 2 for robust fitting, to 5 otherwise.
<br>
    no : int
<br>
        Number of iterations of robust fitting. The value of no should
<br>
        be a nonnegative integer. If the data are well behaved without
<br>
        outliers, then robustness iterations are not needed. In this case
<br>
        set no=0, and set ni=2 to 5 depending on how much security
<br>
        you want that  the seasonal-trend looping converges.
<br>
        If outliers are present then no=3 is a very secure value unless
<br>
        the outliers are radical, in which case no=5 or even 10 might
<br>
        be better.  If no>0 then set ni to 1 or 2.
<br>
        If None, then no is set to 15 for robust fitting, to 0 otherwise.
<br>
    fulloutput : bool
<br>
        If True, a dictionary holding the full output of the original R routine
<br>
        will be returned.
<br>
    returns
<br>
    data : pandas.DataFrame
<br>
        The seasonal, trend, and remainder components
<br>
    """
<br>
</li>
        </ul>
    </details></ul>
</details>

    <details>
        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zzarchive/zutil_features.py:pd_colcat_tonum' href='.//utilmy/zzarchive/zutil_features.py#L837'>pd_colcat_tonum</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>df,<br>colcat = "all",<br>drop_single_label = False,<br>drop_fact_dict = True,<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>    """
<br>
    Encoding a data-set with mixed data (numerical and categorical) to a numerical-only data-set,
<br>
    using the following logic:
<br>
    * categorical with only a single value will be marked as zero (or dropped, if requested)
<br>
    * categorical with two values will be replaced with the result of Pandas `factorize`
<br>
    * categorical with more than two values will be replaced with the result of Pandas `get_dummies`
<br>
    * numerical columns will not be modified
<br>
    **Returns:** DataFrame or (DataFrame, dict). If `drop_fact_dict` is True, returns the encoded DataFrame.
<br>
    else, returns a tuple of the encoded DataFrame and dictionary, where each key is a two-value column, and the
<br>
    value is the original labels, as supplied by Pandas `factorize`. Will be empty if no two-value columns are
<br>
    present in the data-set
<br>
    Parameters
<br>
    ----------
<br>
    df : NumPy ndarray / Pandas DataFrame
<br>
        The data-set to encode
<br>
    colcat : sequence / string
<br>
        A sequence of the nominal (categorical) columns in the dataset. If string, must be 'all' to state that
<br>
        all columns are nominal. If None, nothing happens. Default: 'all'
<br>
    drop_single_label : Boolean, default = False
<br>
        If True, nominal columns with a only a single value will be dropped.
<br>
    drop_fact_dict : Boolean, default = True
<br>
        If True, the return value will be the encoded DataFrame alone. If False, it will be a tuple of
<br>
        the DataFrame and the dictionary of the binary factorization (originating from pd.factorize)
<br>
    """
<br>
</li>
        </ul>
    </details>

        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/py2to3/portfolio_withdate.py:cointegration' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/py2to3/portfolio_withdate.py#L849'>cointegration</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>x,<br>y,<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>  """ Output :
<br>
    coint_t :t-statistic of unit-root test on residuals
<br>
    pvalue :   MacKinnon's approximate p-value based on MacKinnon (1994)
<br>
    crit_value : Critical values for the test statistic at the 1 %, 5 %, and 10 %  Signifiance levels.
<br>

<br>
    The Null hypothesis is that there is no cointegration, the alt hypothesis is that there is cointegrating relationship. 
<br>
    If the pvalue is small, below a critical size:  Reject Null Hypothesis -->  Cointegration
<br>
           pvalue is high --> No Cointegration    
<br>
    
<br>
    Significance level, also denoted as alpha or α, is the probability of rejecting  the null hypothesis when it is true.
<br>
    Probability of incorrectly rejecting a true null hypothesis
<br>

<br>
    P=0.05  , At least 23% (and typically close to 50%)
<br>
    P=0.01  , At least 7% (and typically close to 15%
<br>

<br>
    (-2.9607012342275936,
<br>
    0.038730981052330332, 0,
<br>
    249,
<br>
    {'1%': -3.4568881317725864,
<br>
       '10%': -2.5729936189738876,
<br>
     '5%': -2.8732185133016057},
<br>
      601.96849256295991)
<br>
        It can be seen that the calculated test statistic of -2.96 is smaller than the 5% critical value of -2.87, 
<br>
        which means that we can reject the null hypothesis that  there isn't a cointegrating relationship at the 5% level.
<br>
  """
<br>
</li>
        </ul>
    </details>

def imp_yahoo_periodic_figure(soup, yahoo_figure):
<br>
    values = []; pattern = re.compile(yahoo_figure)
<br>

<br>
    title = soup.find("strong", text=pattern)    # works for the figures printed in bold
<br>
    if title:  row = title.parent.parent
<br>
    else:
<br>
        title = soup.find("td", text=pattern)    # works for any other available figure
<br>
        if title:  row = title.parent
<br>
        else:      sys.exit("Invalid figure '" + yahoo_figure + "' passed.")
<br>

<br>
    cells = row.find_all("td")[1:]    # exclude the <td> with figure name
<br>
    for cell in cells:
<br>
        if cell.text.strip() != yahoo_figure:    # needed because some figures are indented
<br>
            str_value = cell.text.strip().replace(",", "").replace("(", "-").replace(")", "")
<br>
            if str_value == "-": str_value = 0
<br>
            value = int(str_value) * 1000
<br>
            values.append(value)
<br>

<br>
    return values
<br>

def imp_googleIntradayQuote(symbol, freqsec=300, nday=5):
<br>
    ''' Intraday quotes from google. Specify interval seconds and number of days
<br>
    http://www.google.com/finance/getprices?q=7261&i=300&p=3d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v
<br>
    '''
<br>
    url ="http://www.google.com/finance/getprices?q={0}".format(symbol)
<br>
    url +="&i={0}&p={1}d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v".format(freqsec, nday)
<br>
    try :      
<br>
       resp= requests.post(url)
<br>
       csv= resp.text
<br>
       csv= csv.splitlines()
<br>
    except :
<br>
       print('Err Intaday '+symbol)
<br>

<br>
    if len(csv) < 9 :
<br>
      print 'Using Daily',
<br>

<br>
      url='http://www.google.com/finance/historical?q='+symbol+'&i='+str(freqsec)+'&p=3d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v&output=csv'
<br>
      csv = urllib.urlopen(url).readlines()
<br>
      csv.reverse()
<br>
      q=[]
<br>
      for bar in xrange(0,len(csv)-1):
<br>
        ds,open_,high,low,close,volume = csv[bar].rstrip().split(',')
<br>
        if isfloat(open_) and isfloat(high) :
<br>
          open_,high,low,close = [float(x) for x in [open_,high,low,close]]
<br>
          dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds,'%d-%b-%y')
<br>
          q.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
      df= util.pd_array_todataframe(q, ['date','open','high','low','close','volume'])
<br>
      return df
<br>

<br>

<br>
    # print(csv)
<br>
    qq=[]
<br>
    for bar in xrange(7,len(csv)):
<br>
      if csv[bar].count(',')!=5: continue
<br>
      offset,close,high,low,open_,volume = csv[bar].split(',')
<br>
      
<br>
      if offset[0]=='a':
<br>
        day = float(offset[1:])
<br>
        offset = 0
<br>
      else:
<br>
        offset = float(offset)
<br>
      open_, high, low, close = [float(x) for x in [open_,high,low,close]]
<br>
      dt = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(day + (freqsec * offset))
<br>
      #print (dt,open_,high,low,close,volume)
<br>
      qq.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
    df= util.pd_array_todataframe(qq, ['date','open','high','low','close','volume'])
<br>
    return df

<br>
    ''' Daily quotes from google. Date format='yyyymmdd' '''
<br>
    symbol = symbol.upper()
<br>
    start = datetime.date(int(start_date[0:4]),int(start_date[4:6]),int(start_date[6:8]))
<br>
    end =   datetime.date(int(end_date[0:4]),int(end_date[4:6]),int(end_date[6:8]))
<br>
    url ="http://www.google.com/finance/historical?q={0}".format(self.symbol)
<br>
    url +="&startdate={0}&enddate={1}&output=csv".format( start.strftime('%b %d, %Y'),end.strftime('%b %d, %Y'))
<br>
    csv = urllib.urlopen(url).readlines()
<br>
    csv.reverse()
<br>
    # print(url)
<br>
    q=[]
<br>
    for bar in xrange(0,len(csv)-1):
<br>
      ds,open_,high,low,close,volume = csv[bar].rstrip().split(',')
<br>
      if isfloat(open_) and isfloat(high) :
<br>
        open_,high,low,close = [float(x) for x in [open_,high,low,close]]
<br>
        dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds,'%d-%b-%y')
<br>
        q.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
    return q

<br>
  df= df.sort_values(by=['date'], ascending=1)

  df.index = list(np.arange(0,len(df.index)))

  return df

def imp_pd_cashyield(q, duration=10):
<br>
 qbond= copy.deepcopy(q)
<br>
 for id1 in ['close','open','high','low','aclose'] :
<br>
   try:
<br>
     vv= q[id1].values
<br>
     pbond=  100 * np.cumprod( (1 + np.ones(len(vv)) * 0.005/365.0 ))
<br>
     qbond[id1]= pbond
<br>
   except: pass
<br>
 return qbond
<br>

 titlesarray.insert(1,titleticker)

 i = 0

 while(currentpage > 0):

    print str(i) + " page(s) done"

<br>

    while(datalength > 0):

        templist = [stockdata[datalength - 10].text,stockticker[tickerdatalength-1].text,stockdata[datalength - 9].text,stockdata[datalength - 8].text,stockdata[datalength - 7].text,stockdata[datalength - 6].text,stockdata[datalength - 5].text,stockdata[datalength - 4].text,stockdata[datalength - 3].text,stockdata[datalength - 2].text,stockdata[datalength - 1].text,]

        tickerdatalength -= 1

    currentpage -= 20

<br>
 with open('stockoverview.csv', 'wb') as csvfile:

<br>

<br>
 print "Finviz Overview Completed"

 return overview

  def __init__(self):
<br>
    self.symbol = '';    self.exchn=''
<br>
    self.date,self.time,self.open_,self.high,self.low,self.close,self.volume = ([] for _ in range(7))
<br>

<br>
  def append(self,dt,open_,high,low,close,volume):
<br>
    self.date.append(dt.date())
<br>
    self.time.append(dt.time())
<br>
    self.open_.append(float(open_))
<br>
    self.high.append(float(high))
<br>
    self.low.append(float(low))
<br>
    self.close.append(float(close))
<br>
    self.volume.append(int(volume))
<br>

<br>
  def to_csv(self):
<br>
    return ''.join(["{0},{1},{2},{3:.2f},{4:.2f},{5:.2f},{6:.2f},{7}\n".format(self.symbol,
<br>
              self.date[bar].strftime('%Y-%m-%d'),self.time[bar].strftime('%H:%M:%S'),
<br>
              self.open_[bar],self.high[bar],self.low[bar],self.close[bar],self.volume[bar])
<br>
              for bar in xrange(len(self.close))])
<br>

<br>
  def write_csv(self,filename):
<br>
    with open(filename,'w') as f:
<br>
      txt= self.to_csv()
<br>
      f.write(txt)
<br>

<br>
  def read_csv(self,filename):
<br>
    self.symbol = ''
<br>
    self.date,self.time,self.open_,self.high,self.low,self.close,self.volume = ([] for _ in range(7))
<br>
    for line in open(filename,'r'):
<br>
      symbol,ds,ts,open_,high,low,close,volume = line.rstrip().split(',')
<br>
      self.symbol = symbol
<br>
      dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds+' '+ts,self.DATE_FMT+' '+self.TIME_FMT)
<br>
      self.append(dt,open_,high,low,close,volume)
<br>
    return True
<br>

<br>
  def __repr__(self):
<br>
    return self.to_csv()

#####################################################################################
<br>
#---------Run over all the indexes, with time lag -----------------------------------
<br>
def np_similarity(x,y, wwerr=[], type1=0):
<br>
  if type1==2 : return np_distance_l1(x,y, wwerr)
<br>
  if type1==1: return sci.spatial.distance.correlation(x, y)  
<br>
  if type1==0 : return 1-np.corrcoef(x,y)[0,1]
<br>

<br>
def np_distance_l1(x,y, wwerr) :
<br>
 return np.sum(wwerr * np.abs(x-y))  
<br>
  
<br>
#---------------------  Universe Load         ---------------------------------------
<br>
filejpstock= r'E:/_data/stock/daily/20160616/jp'
<br>
sym01= nk400list
<br>

<br>
quotes= imp_txt_getquotes(sym01, filejpstock, startdate=20090101, endate=20160616)
<br>
open1, dateref= date_align(quotes, type1="close")    #Get the data and align dates
<br>
del quotes; util.a_cleanmemory()
<br>

<br>
#util.save_obj(open1, 'close_nk400_2009_2016')
<br>
#util.save_obj(dateref, 'dateref_nk400_2009_2016')
<br>

<br>
open1= util.load_obj('close_nk400_2009_2016')
<br>
dateref= util.load_obj( 'dateref_nk400_2009_2016')
<br>

<br>
nlag=1
<br>
ret_open1 =  getdailyret_fromquotes(open1,nlag)
<br>
del open1
<br>

<br>
#--------------------  Search Asset Input     ---------------------------------------
<br>
name1= '7203' 
<br>
date1= 20160328
<br>
date2= 20160531
<br>
twindow= util.np_findfirst(date2, dateref) - util.np_findfirst(date1, dateref) 
<br>

<br>

<br>
tstartx= util.np_findfirst(date1, dateref)          # Date Index
<br>
stockx= util.np_findfirst(name1, sym01)
<br>
retx= ret_open1[stockx, tstartx:(tstartx+twindow-1)]    # Recent Period
<br>
px= price_normalize_1d(retx)
<br>
nx= len(px)
<br>

<br>

<br>
#----OverWeight for Local Min, Local Max         -----------------------------------
<br>
wwerr= np.ones(nx, dtype=np.float16)
<br>
vvmax= util.np_findlocalmax(px); xprev=0
<br>
for x in vvmax:
<br>
  if x[0] !=0 and np.abs(xprev-x[0]) > 6: 
<br>
    wwerr[max(0,x[0]-1):min(nx,(x[0]+1))]= 1.5;    xprev= x[0] 
<br>

<br>
vvmin= util.np_findlocalmin(px); xprev=0
<br>
for x in vvmin:
<br>
  if x[0] !=0 and np.abs(xprev-x[0]) > 6: 
<br>
    wwerr[max(0,x[0]-1):min(nx,(x[0]+1))]= 1.5;    xprev= x[0] 
<br>

<br>

<br>
#--------------------  Search the Pattern       -------------------------------------
<br>
tmaxx= len(dateref)-1
<br>
similar_list= np.zeros((nstock*(tmaxx-twindow)+1, 3), np.float16)
<br>
i=0
<br>
for iy in range(0, nstock) :
<br>
 for t in range(0, tmaxx-twindow):
<br>
   if iy == stockx and t > tstartx : 
<br>
     pass
<br>
   else :
<br>
    rety= ret_open1[iy, t:(t+twindow-1)]
<br>
    py=   price_normalize_1d(rety)
<br>
    ss= np_similarity(px, py, wwerr=wwerr, type1=2)
<br>
    i+=1
<br>
    similar_list[i,0]= iy
<br>
    similar_list[i,1]= t
<br>
    similar_list[i,2]= ss
<br>

<br>

<br>
 #-------------------Clean the table -------------------------------------------------
<br>
rank= util.np_sortbycolumn(similar_list,2, asc=True)
<br>
for i,x in enumerate(rank) :
<br>
  if rank[i,2]==0.0 : rank[i,2]= 1000         # Empty cell
<br>
  if rank[i,1]> tstartx-3 : rank[i,2]= 100    # Start Element
<br>
rank= util.np_sortbycolumn(rank,2, asc=True)  
<br>

<br>

<br>
 #----- Show Similar Stocks ---------------------------------------------------------
<br>
show_only_different_time= True
<br>

<br>
for i in range(0,10) :
<br>
 tstarti= rank[i,1]
<br>
 stocki= int(rank[i,0])
<br>
 
<br>
 if show_only_different_time and tstarti < tstartx-1  :
<br>
   py= price_normalize100(ret_open1[stocki, tstarti:(tstarti+twindow-1)]) 
<br>

<br>
   namei= sym01[stocki]
<br>
   namefulli= nk400name[util.np_findfirst(namei, nk400list)]
<br>

<br>
   tit= namei+ " " +namefulli+ " " + str(dateref[tstarti])          
<br>
   plot_price(px-100, py-100, label=('Similar '+tit, 'Time','% Var') )
<br>

<br>

<br>
kix= util.np_findfirst(name1, statsjp[:,0, ilag])
<br>

<br>
plot_price(price_normalize100(ret_open1[157, 86:86+twindow-1])-100,px-100   )
<br>

        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>   '''
<br>
   http://word.bitly.com/post/74069870671/optimizing-text-processing
<br>

<br>
import sys
<br>
from collections import defaultdict
<br>
OUT_FILES = defaultdict(dict)
<br>

<br>
open_outfiles()  # open all files I could possibly need
<br>

<br>
for line in sys.stdin:
<br>
    # 1. parse line for account_id and metric_type
<br>
    key = line.split(',')
<br>
    account_id = key[ACCOUNT_ID_INDEX][1:] # strip leading quote
<br>

<br>
    # 2. write to appropriate file for account_id and metric_type
<br>
    OUT_FILES[account_id][key[METRIC_TYPE_INDEX]].write(line)
<br>

<br>
   close_outfiles()  # close all the files we opened
<br>

<br>
   '''
<br>
</li>
        </ul>

    <details>
        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/util.py:os_print_tofile' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/util.py#L908'>os_print_tofile</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>vv,<br>file1,<br>mode1 = 'a',<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>    '''
<br>
    Here is a list of the different modes of opening a file:
<br>
r
<br>
Opens a file for reading only. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode.
<br>

<br>
rb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for reading only in binary format. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode.
<br>
r+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file.
<br>
rb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing in binary format. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file.
<br>
w
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing.
<br>
wb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only in binary format. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing.
<br>
w+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
wb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading in binary format. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
a
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing.
<br>
ab
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing.
<br>
a+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
ab+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
To open a text file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "r")
<br>

<br>
To read a text file, use:
<br>
print fh.read()
<br>

<br>
To read one line at a time, use:
<br>
print fh.readline()
<br>

<br>
To read a list of lines use:
<br>
print fh.readlines()
<br>

<br>
To write to a file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "w")
<br>
lines_of_text = ["a line of text", "another line of text", "a third line"]
<br>
fh.writelines(lines_of_text)
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
To append to file, use:
<br>
fh = open("Hello.txt", "a")
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
    '''
<br>
</li>

<br>

<br>
    you would call pivot with the arguments:
<br>

<br>
    newList = pivot(listOfDicts, ('Name',), ('Year',), 'Value')
<br>

        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>df,<br>targetype = str,<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br> '''
<br>
 https://www.azavea.com/blog/2014/03/24/solving-unicode-problems-in-python-2-7/
<br>
 Nearly every Unicode problem can be solved by the proper application of these tools;
<br>
 they will help you build an airlock to keep the inside of your code nice and clean:
<br>

<br>
encode(): Gets you from Unicode -> bytes
<br>
decode(): Gets you from bytes -> Unicode
<br>
codecs.open(encoding=”utf-8″): Read and write files directly to/from Unicode (you can use any encoding,
<br>
 not just utf-8, but utf-8 is most common).
<br>
u”: Makes your string literals into Unicode objects rather than byte sequences.
<br>
Warning: Don’t use encode() on bytes or decode() on Unicode objects
<br>

<br>
>>> uni_greeting % utf8_name
<br>
Traceback (most recent call last):
<br>
 File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
<br>
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 3: ordinal not in range(128)
<br>
# Solution:
<br>
>>> uni_greeting % utf8_name.decode('utf-8')
<br>
u'Hi, my name is Josxe9.'
<br>

<br>
 '''
<br>
</li>
        </ul>

<br>
cal = USFederalHolidayCalendar()
<br>

<br>
holidays.head()
<br>

<br>
holidays_all = pd.concat([holidays, "Day Before " + holidays.shift(-1, 'D'),  "Day After " + holidays.shift(1, 'D')])

<br>
holidays_all.head()
<br>

<br>
from pandas.tseries.offsets import CustomBusinessDay
<br>
from pandas.tseries.holiday import USFederalHolidayCalendar
<br>
bday_us = CustomBusinessDay(calendar=USFederalHolidayCalendar())
<br>
dateref[-1] - bday_us- bday_us
<br>

<br>

        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>func,<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>    '''Decorator to run a function as a process.
<br>
    Be sure that every argument and the return value is *pickable*.
<br>
    The created process is joined, so the code does not  run in parallel.
<br>
    @processify
<br>

<br>
    def test():
<br>
      return os.getpid()
<br>

<br>
    @processify
<br>
    def test_deadlock():
<br>
      return range(30000)
<br>

<br>
   @processify
<br>
   def test_exception():
<br>
     raise RuntimeError('xyz')
<br>

<br>
   def test():
<br>
     print os.getpid()
<br>
     print test_function()
<br>
     print len(test_deadlock())
<br>
     test_exception()
<br>

<br>
   if __name__ == '__main__':
<br>
     test()
<br>

<br>
    '''
<br>
</li>
        </ul>

    <details>
        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/py2to3/util_min.py:os_print_tofile' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/py2to3/util_min.py#L309'>os_print_tofile</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>vv,<br>file1,<br>mode1 = 'a',<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>    '''
<br>
    Here is a list of the different modes of opening a file:
<br>
r
<br>
Opens a file for reading only. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode.
<br>

<br>
rb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for reading only in binary format. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode.
<br>
r+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file.
<br>
rb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing in binary format. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file.
<br>
w
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing.
<br>
wb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only in binary format. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing.
<br>
w+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
wb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading in binary format. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
a
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing.
<br>
ab
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing.
<br>
a+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
ab+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
To open a text file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "r")
<br>

<br>
To read a text file, use:
<br>
print fh.read()
<br>

<br>
To read one line at a time, use:
<br>
print fh.readline()
<br>

<br>
To read a list of lines use:
<br>
print fh.readlines()
<br>

<br>
To write to a file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "w")
<br>
lines_of_text = ["a line of text", "another line of text", "a third line"]
<br>
fh.writelines(lines_of_text)
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
To append to file, use:
<br>
fh = open("Hello.txt", "a")
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
    '''
<br>
</li>
        </ul>

    :name sort_by_len: Sort by the sequence lenght for the train,
<br>
        valid and test set. This allow faster execution as it cause
<br>
        less padding per minibatch. Another mechanism must be used to
<br>
        shuffle the train set at each epoch.

<br>
    '''

    <details>
        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/py3/util.py:os_print_tofile' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/py3/util.py#L875'>os_print_tofile</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>vv,<br>file1,<br>mode1 = 'a',<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>    '''
<br>
    Here is a list of the different modes of opening a file:
<br>
r
<br>
Opens a file for reading only. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode.
<br>

<br>
rb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for reading only in binary format. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode.
<br>
r+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file.
<br>
rb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing in binary format. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file.
<br>
w
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing.
<br>
wb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only in binary format. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing.
<br>
w+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
wb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading in binary format. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
a
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing.
<br>
ab
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing.
<br>
a+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
ab+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
To open a text file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "r")
<br>

<br>
To read a text file, use:
<br>
print fh.read()
<br>

<br>
To read one line at a time, use:
<br>
print fh.readline()
<br>

<br>
To read a list of lines use:
<br>
print fh.readlines()
<br>

<br>
To write to a file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "w")
<br>
lines_of_text = ["a line of text", "another line of text", "a third line"]
<br>
fh.writelines(lines_of_text)
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
To append to file, use:
<br>
fh = open("Hello.txt", "a")
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
    '''
<br>
</li>
        </ul>

import os
<br>
import pyexcel
<br>
import datetime
<br>

<br>
from sqlalchemy import create_engine
<br>
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base
<br>
from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, String, Float, Date
<br>
from sqlalchemy.orm import sessionmaker
<br>

<br>

<br>
engine = create_engine("sqlite:///birth.db")
<br>
Base = declarative_base()
<br>
Session = sessionmaker(bind=engine)
<br>

<br>

<br>
# here is the destination table
<br>
class BirthRegister(Base):
<br>
    __tablename__ = 'birth'
<br>
    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
<br>
    name = Column(String)
<br>
    weight = Column(Float)
<br>
    birth = Column(Date)
<br>

<br>

<br>
Base.metadata.create_all(engine)
<br>

<br>

<br>
# create fixture
<br>
data = [
<br>
    ["name", "weight", "birth"],
<br>
    ["Adam", 3.4, datetime.date(2015, 2, 3)],
<br>
    ["Smith", 4.2, datetime.date(2014, 11, 12)]
<br>
]
<br>
pyexcel.save_as(array=data,
<br>
                dest_file_name="birth.xls")
<br>

<br>
# import the xls file
<br>
session = Session()  # obtain a sql session
<br>
pyexcel.save_as(file_name="birth.xls",
<br>
                name_columns_by_row=0,
<br>
                dest_session=session,
<br>
                dest_table=BirthRegister)
<br>

<br>
# verify results
<br>
sheet = pyexcel.get_sheet(session=session, table=BirthRegister)
<br>
print(sheet)
<br>

<br>
session.close()
<br>
os.unlink('birth.db')
<br>
os.unlink("birth.xls")
<br>

<br>
 This code uses the openpyxl package for playing around with excel using Python code
<br>
 to convert complete excel workbook (all sheets) to an SQLite database
<br>
 The code assumes that the first row of every sheet is the column name
<br>
 Every sheet is stored in a separate table
<br>
 The sheet name is assigned as the table name for every sheet
<br>
 '''

<br>
As we previously mentioned, the crosstab function is part of a PostgreSQL extension called tablefunc. To call the crosstab function,

you must first enable the tablefunc extension by executing the following SQL command:
<br>
CREATE extension tablefunc;
<br>

SELECT *
<br>
FROM crosstab( 'select student, subject, evaluation_result from evaluations order by 1,2')
<br>
AS final_result(Student TEXT, Geography NUMERIC,History NUMERIC,Language NUMERIC,Maths NUMERIC,Music NUMERIC);
<br>

<br>

SELECT *
<br>
FROM crosstab( 'select student, subject, evaluation_result from evaluations
<br>
                where extract (month from evaluation_day) = 7 order by 1,2',
<br>
                'select name from subject order by 1')
<br>
     AS final_result(Student TEXT, Geography NUMERIC,History NUMERIC,Language NUMERIC,Maths NUMERIC,Music NUMERIC);
<br>

<br>

<br>

The parameter how instructs Pandas to use the inner-join which means it will only combine such rows which belong to both of the tables. Therefore we’ll not receive any NaN-rows. But in some cases this could be desirable. Then use the alternative options like left, right or outer.

        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/py3/util.py:np_pivotable_create' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/py3/util.py#L2847'>np_pivotable_create</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>table,<br>left,<br>top,<br>value,<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>    """
<br>
    Creates a cross-tab or pivot table from a normalised input table. Use this
<br>
    function to 'denormalize' a table of normalized records.
<br>

<br>
    * The table argument can be a list of dictionaries or a Table object.
<br>
    (http://aspn.activestate.com/ASPN/Cookbook/Python/Recipe/334621)
<br>
    * The left argument is a tuple of headings which are displayed down the
<br>
    left side of the new table.
<br>
    * The top argument is a tuple of headings which are displayed across the
<br>
    top of the new table.
<br>
    Tuples are used so that multiple element headings and columns can be used.
<br>

<br>
    E.g. To transform the list (listOfDicts):
<br>

<br>
    Name,   Year,  Value
<br>
    -----------------------
<br>
    'Simon', 2004, 32
<br>
    'Simon', 2005, 128
<br>
    'Russel', 2004, 64
<br>
    'Eric', 2004, 52
<br>
    'Russel', 2005, 32
<br>

<br>
    into the new list:
<br>

<br>
    'Name',   2004, 2005
<br>
    ------------------------
<br>
    'Simon',  32,     128
<br>
    'Russel',  64,     32
<br>
    'Eric',   52,     NA
<br>

<br>
    you would call pivot with the arguments:

<br>
encode(): Gets you from Unicode -> bytes

decode(): Gets you from bytes -> Unicode
<br>
codecs.open(encoding=”utf-8″): Read and write files directly to/from Unicode (you can use any encoding,
<br>
 not just utf-8, but utf-8 is most common).
<br>
u”: Makes your string literals into Unicode objects rather than byte sequences.
<br>
Warning: Don’t use encode() on bytes or decode() on Unicode objects
<br>

<br>
>>> uni_greeting % utf8_name
<br>
Traceback (most recent call last):
<br>
 File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
<br>
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 3: ordinal not in range(128)
<br>
# Solution:
<br>
>>> uni_greeting % utf8_name.decode('utf-8')
<br>

<br>

        <li>Docs:<br>   '''
<br>
   https://jakevdp.github.io/blog/2015/07/23/learning-seattles-work-habits-from-bicycle-counts/
<br>

<br>
from pandas.tseries.holiday import USFederalHolidayCalendar
<br>
cal = USFederalHolidayCalendar()
<br>
holidays = cal.holidays('2012', '2016', return_name=True)

   @processify
<br>
   def test_exception():
<br>

<br>

<br>
   def test():
<br>
     print os.getpid()
<br>
     print test_function()
<br>
     print len(test_deadlock())
<br>
     test_exception()
<br>

<br>
   if __name__ == '__main__':
<br>
     test()
<br>

<br>
    '''

        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/util_min.py:os_print_tofile' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/util_min.py#L309'>os_print_tofile</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>vv,<br>file1,<br>mode1 = 'a',<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>    '''
<br>
    Here is a list of the different modes of opening a file:
<br>
r
<br>
Opens a file for reading only. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode.
<br>

<br>
rb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for reading only in binary format. The file pointer is placed at the beginning of the file. This is the default mode.
<br>
r+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file.
<br>
rb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both reading and writing in binary format. The file pointer will be at the beginning of the file.
<br>
w
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing.
<br>
wb
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for writing only in binary format. Overwrites the file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for writing.
<br>
w+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
wb+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both writing and reading in binary format. Overwrites the existing file if the file exists. If the file does not exist, creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
a
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing.
<br>
ab
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for appending in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. That is, the file is in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for writing.
<br>
a+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
ab+
<br>

<br>
Opens a file for both appending and reading in binary format. The file pointer is at the end of the file if the file exists. The file opens in the append mode. If the file does not exist, it creates a new file for reading and writing.
<br>
To open a text file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "r")
<br>

<br>
To read a text file, use:
<br>
print fh.read()
<br>

<br>
To read one line at a time, use:
<br>
print fh.readline()
<br>

<br>
To read a list of lines use:
<br>
print fh.readlines()
<br>

<br>
To write to a file, use:
<br>
fh = open("hello.txt", "w")
<br>
lines_of_text = ["a line of text", "another line of text", "a third line"]
<br>
fh.writelines(lines_of_text)
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
To append to file, use:
<br>
fh = open("Hello.txt", "a")
<br>
fh.close()
<br>

<br>
    '''
<br>
</li>

<br>

<br>
import sys
<br>
from collections import defaultdict
<br>
OUT_FILES = defaultdict(dict)
<br>

<br>
open_outfiles()  # open all files I could possibly need
<br>

<br>
for line in sys.stdin:
<br>
    # 1. parse line for account_id and metric_type
<br>
    key = line.split(',')
<br>
    account_id = key[ACCOUNT_ID_INDEX][1:] # strip leading quote
<br>

<br>
    # 2. write to appropriate file for account_id and metric_type
<br>
    OUT_FILES[account_id][key[METRIC_TYPE_INDEX]].write(line)
<br>

<br>
   close_outfiles()  # close all the files we opened
<br>

<br>
   '''

  from catboost import Pool, CatBoostClassifier

        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/portfolio_withdate.py:cointegration' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/portfolio_withdate.py#L849'>cointegration</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>x,<br>y,<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>  """ Output :
<br>
    coint_t :t-statistic of unit-root test on residuals
<br>
    pvalue :   MacKinnon's approximate p-value based on MacKinnon (1994)
<br>
    crit_value : Critical values for the test statistic at the 1 %, 5 %, and 10 %  Signifiance levels.
<br>

<br>
    The Null hypothesis is that there is no cointegration, the alt hypothesis is that there is cointegrating relationship. 
<br>
    If the pvalue is small, below a critical size:  Reject Null Hypothesis -->  Cointegration
<br>
           pvalue is high --> No Cointegration    
<br>
    
<br>
    Significance level, also denoted as alpha or α, is the probability of rejecting  the null hypothesis when it is true.
<br>
    Probability of incorrectly rejecting a true null hypothesis
<br>

<br>
    P=0.05  , At least 23% (and typically close to 50%)
<br>
    P=0.01  , At least 7% (and typically close to 15%
<br>

<br>
    (-2.9607012342275936,
<br>
    0.038730981052330332, 0,
<br>
    249,
<br>
    {'1%': -3.4568881317725864,
<br>
       '10%': -2.5729936189738876,
<br>
     '5%': -2.8732185133016057},
<br>
      601.96849256295991)
<br>
        It can be seen that the calculated test statistic of -2.96 is smaller than the 5% critical value of -2.87, 
<br>
        which means that we can reject the null hypothesis that  there isn't a cointegrating relationship at the 5% level.
<br>
  """
<br>
</li>
        </ul>
    </details>

def imp_yahoo_periodic_figure(soup, yahoo_figure):
<br>
    values = []; pattern = re.compile(yahoo_figure)
<br>

<br>
    title = soup.find("strong", text=pattern)    # works for the figures printed in bold
<br>
    if title:  row = title.parent.parent
<br>
    else:
<br>
        title = soup.find("td", text=pattern)    # works for any other available figure
<br>
        if title:  row = title.parent
<br>
        else:      sys.exit("Invalid figure '" + yahoo_figure + "' passed.")
<br>

<br>
    cells = row.find_all("td")[1:]    # exclude the <td> with figure name
<br>
    for cell in cells:
<br>
        if cell.text.strip() != yahoo_figure:    # needed because some figures are indented
<br>
            str_value = cell.text.strip().replace(",", "").replace("(", "-").replace(")", "")
<br>
            if str_value == "-": str_value = 0
<br>
            value = int(str_value) * 1000
<br>
            values.append(value)
<br>

<br>
    return values
<br>

def imp_googleIntradayQuote(symbol, freqsec=300, nday=5):
<br>
    ''' Intraday quotes from google. Specify interval seconds and number of days
<br>
    http://www.google.com/finance/getprices?q=7261&i=300&p=3d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v
<br>
    '''
<br>
    url ="http://www.google.com/finance/getprices?q={0}".format(symbol)
<br>
    url +="&i={0}&p={1}d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v".format(freqsec, nday)
<br>
    try :      
<br>
       resp= requests.post(url)
<br>
       csv= resp.text
<br>
       csv= csv.splitlines()
<br>
    except :
<br>
       print('Err Intaday '+symbol)
<br>

<br>
    if len(csv) < 9 :
<br>
      print 'Using Daily',
<br>

<br>
      url='http://www.google.com/finance/historical?q='+symbol+'&i='+str(freqsec)+'&p=3d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v&output=csv'
<br>
      csv = urllib.urlopen(url).readlines()
<br>
      csv.reverse()
<br>
      q=[]
<br>
      for bar in xrange(0,len(csv)-1):
<br>
        ds,open_,high,low,close,volume = csv[bar].rstrip().split(',')
<br>
        if isfloat(open_) and isfloat(high) :
<br>
          open_,high,low,close = [float(x) for x in [open_,high,low,close]]
<br>
          dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds,'%d-%b-%y')
<br>
          q.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
      df= util.pd_array_todataframe(q, ['date','open','high','low','close','volume'])
<br>
      return df
<br>

<br>

<br>
    # print(csv)
<br>
    qq=[]
<br>
    for bar in xrange(7,len(csv)):
<br>
      if csv[bar].count(',')!=5: continue
<br>
      offset,close,high,low,open_,volume = csv[bar].split(',')
<br>
      
<br>
      if offset[0]=='a':
<br>
        day = float(offset[1:])
<br>
        offset = 0
<br>
      else:
<br>
        offset = float(offset)
<br>
      open_, high, low, close = [float(x) for x in [open_,high,low,close]]
<br>
      dt = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(day + (freqsec * offset))
<br>
      #print (dt,open_,high,low,close,volume)
<br>
      qq.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
    df= util.pd_array_todataframe(qq, ['date','open','high','low','close','volume'])
<br>
    return df

def imp_pd_cashyield(q, duration=10):
<br>
 qbond= copy.deepcopy(q)
<br>
 for id1 in ['close','open','high','low','aclose'] :
<br>
   try:
<br>
     vv= q[id1].values
<br>
     pbond=  100 * np.cumprod( (1 + np.ones(len(vv)) * 0.005/365.0 ))
<br>
     qbond[id1]= pbond
<br>
   except: pass
<br>
 return qbond

class Quote(object):
<br>
  DATE_FMT = '%Y-%m-%d';  TIME_FMT = '%H:%M:%S'
<br>

<br>
  def __init__(self):
<br>
    self.symbol = '';    self.exchn=''
<br>
    self.date,self.time,self.open_,self.high,self.low,self.close,self.volume = ([] for _ in range(7))
<br>

<br>
  def append(self,dt,open_,high,low,close,volume):
<br>
    self.date.append(dt.date())
<br>
    self.time.append(dt.time())
<br>
    self.open_.append(float(open_))
<br>
    self.high.append(float(high))
<br>
    self.low.append(float(low))
<br>
    self.close.append(float(close))
<br>
    self.volume.append(int(volume))
<br>

<br>
  def to_csv(self):
<br>
    return ''.join(["{0},{1},{2},{3:.2f},{4:.2f},{5:.2f},{6:.2f},{7}\n".format(self.symbol,
<br>
              self.date[bar].strftime('%Y-%m-%d'),self.time[bar].strftime('%H:%M:%S'),
<br>
              self.open_[bar],self.high[bar],self.low[bar],self.close[bar],self.volume[bar])
<br>
              for bar in xrange(len(self.close))])
<br>

<br>
  def write_csv(self,filename):
<br>
    with open(filename,'w') as f:
<br>
      txt= self.to_csv()
<br>
      f.write(txt)
<br>

<br>
  def read_csv(self,filename):
<br>
    self.symbol = ''
<br>
    self.date,self.time,self.open_,self.high,self.low,self.close,self.volume = ([] for _ in range(7))
<br>
    for line in open(filename,'r'):
<br>
      symbol,ds,ts,open_,high,low,close,volume = line.rstrip().split(',')
<br>
      self.symbol = symbol
<br>
      dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds+' '+ts,self.DATE_FMT+' '+self.TIME_FMT)
<br>
      self.append(dt,open_,high,low,close,volume)
<br>
    return True
<br>

<br>
  def __repr__(self):
<br>
    return self.to_csv()
<br>

#---------Run over all the indexes, with time lag -----------------------------------
<br>
def np_similarity(x,y, wwerr=[], type1=0):
<br>
  if type1==2 : return np_distance_l1(x,y, wwerr)
<br>
  if type1==1: return sci.spatial.distance.correlation(x, y)  
<br>
  if type1==0 : return 1-np.corrcoef(x,y)[0,1]
<br>

<br>
def np_distance_l1(x,y, wwerr) :
<br>
 return np.sum(wwerr * np.abs(x-y))  
<br>

import os

<br>
engine = create_engine("sqlite:///birth.db")
<br>

<br>

<br>

<br>
# here is the destination table
<br>
class BirthRegister(Base):
<br>
    __tablename__ = 'birth'
<br>
    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
<br>
    name = Column(String)
<br>
    weight = Column(Float)
<br>
    birth = Column(Date)

<br>

<br>

]

<br>
                dest_file_name="birth.xls")

<br>
                dest_session=session,

                dest_table=BirthRegister)

sheet = pyexcel.get_sheet(session=session, table=BirthRegister)

print(sheet)

<br>
session.close()

os.unlink('birth.db')

os.unlink("birth.xls")

http://blog.brakmic.com/data-science-for-losers-part-2/
<br>

<br>
Here we instruct Pandas to merge two tables by using certain primary keys from both when combining their rows into a new table. The parameter how instructs Pandas to use the inner-join which means it will only combine such rows which belong to both of the tables. Therefore we’ll not receive any NaN-rows. But in some cases this could be desirable. Then use the alternative options like left, right or outer.
<br>

<br>
Pivots with Tables from SQLAlchemy
<br>

<br>
And of course it’s possible to generate the same pivot tables with data that came from SQLAlchemy.
<br>
They’re nothing else but DataFrames all the way down. OK, not absolutely all the way down,
<br>
because there are also Series and NumPy arrays etc.,
<br>
but this is a little bit too much of knowledge for Losers like us. Maybe in some later articles.
<br>

        <summary>
        function | <a name='utilmy/zarchive/portfolio.py:cointegration' href='.//utilmy/zarchive/portfolio.py#L639'>cointegration</a>
        </summary>
        <ul>
        <li>Args:</li>
        <ul>x,<br>y,<br></ul>
        <li>Docs:<br>  """ Output :
<br>
    coint_t :t-statistic of unit-root test on residuals
<br>
    pvalue :   MacKinnon's approximate p-value based on MacKinnon (1994)
<br>
    crit_value : Critical values for the test statistic at the 1 %, 5 %, and 10 %  Signifiance levels.
<br>

<br>
    The Null hypothesis is that there is no cointegration, the alt hypothesis is that there is cointegrating relationship. 
<br>
    If the pvalue is small, below a critical size:  Reject Null Hypothesis -->  Cointegration
<br>
           pvalue is high --> No Cointegration    
<br>
    
<br>
    Significance level, also denoted as alpha or α, is the probability of rejecting  the null hypothesis when it is true.
<br>
    Probability of incorrectly rejecting a true null hypothesis
<br>

<br>
    P=0.05  , At least 23% (and typically close to 50%)
<br>
    P=0.01  , At least 7% (and typically close to 15%
<br>

<br>
    (-2.9607012342275936,
<br>
    0.038730981052330332, 0,
<br>
    249,
<br>
    {'1%': -3.4568881317725864,
<br>
       '10%': -2.5729936189738876,
<br>
     '5%': -2.8732185133016057},
<br>
      601.96849256295991)
<br>
        It can be seen that the calculated test statistic of -2.96 is smaller than the 5% critical value of -2.87, 
<br>
        which means that we can reject the null hypothesis that  there isn't a cointegrating relationship at the 5% level.
<br>
  """
<br>
</li>
        </ul>

        <li>Docs:<br>    """Return dataframe of requested dataset from Quandl.

    :param dataset: str or list, depending on single dataset usage or multiset usage

            Dataset codes are available on the Quandl website

<br>
    :param str start_date, end_date: Optional datefilers, otherwise entire dataset is returned
<br>
    :param str collapse: Options are daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, annual
<br>
    :param str transform: options are diff, rdiff, cumul, and normalize
<br>
    :param int rows: Number of rows which will be returned
<br>
    :param str order: options are asc, desc. Default: `asc`
<br>

def imp_yahoo_periodic_figure(soup, yahoo_figure):
<br>
    values = []; pattern = re.compile(yahoo_figure)
<br>

<br>
    title = soup.find("strong", text=pattern)    # works for the figures printed in bold
<br>
    if title:  row = title.parent.parent
<br>
    else:
<br>
        title = soup.find("td", text=pattern)    # works for any other available figure
<br>
        if title:  row = title.parent
<br>
        else:      sys.exit("Invalid figure '" + yahoo_figure + "' passed.")
<br>

<br>
    cells = row.find_all("td")[1:]    # exclude the <td> with figure name
<br>
    for cell in cells:
<br>
        if cell.text.strip() != yahoo_figure:    # needed because some figures are indented
<br>
            str_value = cell.text.strip().replace(",", "").replace("(", "-").replace(")", "")
<br>
            if str_value == "-": str_value = 0
<br>
            value = int(str_value) * 1000
<br>
            values.append(value)
<br>

<br>
    return values
<br>

def imp_googleIntradayQuote(symbol, freqsec=300, nday=5):
<br>
    ''' Intraday quotes from google. Specify interval seconds and number of days
<br>
    http://www.google.com/finance/getprices?q=7261&i=300&p=3d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v
<br>
    '''
<br>
    url ="http://www.google.com/finance/getprices?q={0}".format(symbol)
<br>
    url +="&i={0}&p={1}d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v".format(freqsec, nday)
<br>
    try :      
<br>
       resp= requests.post(url)
<br>
       csv= resp.text
<br>
       csv= csv.splitlines()
<br>
    except :
<br>
       print('Err Intaday '+symbol)
<br>

<br>
    if len(csv) < 9 :
<br>
      print 'Using Daily',
<br>

<br>
      url='http://www.google.com/finance/historical?q='+symbol+'&i='+str(freqsec)+'&p=3d&f=d,o,h,l,c,v&output=csv'
<br>
      csv = urllib.urlopen(url).readlines()
<br>
      csv.reverse()
<br>
      q=[]
<br>
      for bar in xrange(0,len(csv)-1):
<br>
        ds,open_,high,low,close,volume = csv[bar].rstrip().split(',')
<br>
        if isfloat(open_) and isfloat(high) :
<br>
          open_,high,low,close = [float(x) for x in [open_,high,low,close]]
<br>
          dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds,'%d-%b-%y')
<br>
          q.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
      df= util.pd_array_todataframe(q, ['date','open','high','low','close','volume'])
<br>
      return df
<br>

<br>

<br>
    # print(csv)
<br>
    qq=[]
<br>
    for bar in xrange(7,len(csv)):
<br>
      if csv[bar].count(',')!=5: continue
<br>
      offset,close,high,low,open_,volume = csv[bar].split(',')
<br>
      
<br>
      if offset[0]=='a':
<br>
        day = float(offset[1:])
<br>
        offset = 0
<br>
      else:
<br>
        offset = float(offset)
<br>
      open_, high, low, close = [float(x) for x in [open_,high,low,close]]
<br>
      dt = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(day + (freqsec * offset))
<br>
      #print (dt,open_,high,low,close,volume)
<br>
      qq.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
    df= util.pd_array_todataframe(qq, ['date','open','high','low','close','volume'])
<br>
    return df

def imp_googleQuote(symbol, start_date='20160101', end_date= '20160101') : # datetime.date.today().isoformat()):
<br>
    ''' Daily quotes from google. Date format='yyyymmdd' '''
<br>
    symbol = symbol.upper()
<br>
    start = datetime.date(int(start_date[0:4]),int(start_date[4:6]),int(start_date[6:8]))
<br>
    end =   datetime.date(int(end_date[0:4]),int(end_date[4:6]),int(end_date[6:8]))
<br>
    url ="http://www.google.com/finance/historical?q={0}".format(symbol)
<br>
    url +="&startdate={0}&enddate={1}&output=csv".format( start.strftime('%b %d, %Y'),end.strftime('%b %d, %Y'))
<br>
    csv = urllib.urlopen(url).readlines()
<br>
    csv.reverse()
<br>
    # print(url)
<br>
    q=[]
<br>
    for bar in xrange(0,len(csv)-1):
<br>
      ds,open_,high,low,close,volume = csv[bar].rstrip().split(',')
<br>
      if isfloat(open_) and isfloat(high) :
<br>
        open_,high,low,close = [float(x) for x in [open_, high, low, close]  ]
<br>
        dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds,'%d-%b-%y')
<br>
        q.append([dt,open_,high,low,close,volume])
<br>
    return  pd.DataFrame(np.array(q), columns= ["date","open","high","low","Close","volume"])

def imp_hdfs_removeDuplicate(filepd='E:\_data\stock\intraday_google.h5') :
<br>
  #-------Clean by removing duplicate-------------------------------------------------
<br>
  store = pd.HDFStore(filepd)
<br>
  for symbol in store.keys():
<br>
    #qq= imp_hdfs_getquote(filepd, symbol);
<br>
    qq= store.select(symbol[1:])
<br>
    qq= qq.drop_duplicates(subset='date', take_last=True)
<br>
    qq= qq.sort('date', ascending=1)
<br>
    qq.index = list(np.arange(0,len(qq.index)))
<br>

<br>
    store.remove(symbol); store.append(symbol, qq);
<br>
  store.close()

def imp_pd_tohdfs(sym, qqlist, filenameh5, fromzone='Japan', tozone='UTC') :

<br>
  store = pd.HDFStore(filenameh5);

  for k, df2 in enumerate(qqlist) :

    df= copy.deepcopy(df2)

    df['date']= datetime_toint(df.date.values)

    symbol= sym[k].replace('-','_')

      store.append(symbol, df)  # , data_columns=True

      # print(symbol + str(df.date.values[-1]))

    else :

      qq= pd.concat([qq, df], ignore_index=True)

      qq= qq.sort('date', ascending=1)

      print(symbol + str(qq.date.values[-1]))

<br>

def imp_pd_merge(df1, df2) :
<br>
  df= pd.concat([df1, df2], axis=0)
<br>
  df= df.drop_duplicates(subset='date', keep='last')
<br>
  df= df.sort_values(by=['date'], ascending=1)
<br>
  df.index = list(np.arange(0,len(df.index)))
<br>
  return df

def imp_pd_cashyield(q, duration=10):
<br>
 qbond= copy.deepcopy(q)
<br>
 for id1 in ['close','open','high','low','aclose'] :
<br>
   try:
<br>
     vv= q[id1].values
<br>
     pbond=  100 * np.cumprod( (1 + np.ones(len(vv)) * 0.005/365.0 ))
<br>
     qbond[id1]= pbond
<br>
   except: pass
<br>
 return qbond
<br>

def imp_pd_yield_tobond(q, duration=10):
<br>
 qbond= copy.deepcopy(q)
<br>
 for id1 in ['close','open','high','low','aclose'] :
<br>
   try:
<br>
     vv= q[id1].values
<br>
     pbond=  1/ np.power(1+ vv*0.01,duration) *100
<br>
     qbond[id1]= pbond
<br>
#     print 'ok'

   except: pass
<br>
 return qbond

from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
<br>
import csv,datetime, requests
<br>
def imp_finviz():
<br>
 #pdb.set_trace() - python step by step debugger command
<br>
 print "Finviz Overview Start"
<br>
 url = "http://www.finviz.com/screener.ashx?v=111&f=geo_usa"
<br>
 response = requests.get(url)
<br>
 html = response.content
<br>
 soup = BeautifulSoup(html)
<br>
 firstcount = soup.find_all('option')
<br>
 lastnum = len(firstcount) - 1
<br>
 lastpagenum = firstcount[lastnum].attrs['value']
<br>
 currentpage = int(lastpagenum)
<br>

<br>
 alldata = []
<br>
 templist = []
<br>
 # Overview = 111, Valuation = 121, Financial = 161, Ownership = 131, Performance = 141
<br>
 #pagesarray = [111,121,161,131,141]
<br>
 titleslist = soup.find_all('td',{"class" : "table-top"})
<br>
 titleslisttickerid = soup.find_all('td',{"class" : "table-top-s"})
<br>
 titleticker = titleslisttickerid[0].text
<br>
 titlesarray = []
<br>
 for title in titleslist:
<br>
    titlesarray.append(title.text)
<br>

<br>
 titlesarray.insert(1,titleticker)
<br>
 i = 0
<br>

<br>
 while(currentpage > 0):
<br>
    i += 1
<br>
    print str(i) + " page(s) done"
<br>
    secondurl = "http://www.finviz.com/screener.ashx?v=" + str(111) + "&f=geo_usa" + "&r=" + str(currentpage)
<br>
    secondresponse = requests.get(secondurl)
<br>
    secondhtml = secondresponse.content
<br>
    secondsoup = BeautifulSoup(secondhtml)
<br>
    stockdata = secondsoup.find_all('a', {"class" : "screener-link"})
<br>
    stockticker = secondsoup.find_all('a', {"class" : "screener-link-primary"})
<br>
    datalength = len(stockdata)
<br>
    tickerdatalength = len(stockticker)
<br>

<br>
    while(datalength > 0):
<br>
        templist = [stockdata[datalength - 10].text,stockticker[tickerdatalength-1].text,stockdata[datalength - 9].text,stockdata[datalength - 8].text,stockdata[datalength - 7].text,stockdata[datalength - 6].text,stockdata[datalength - 5].text,stockdata[datalength - 4].text,stockdata[datalength - 3].text,stockdata[datalength - 2].text,stockdata[datalength - 1].text,]
<br>
        alldata.append(templist)
<br>
        templist = []
<br>
        datalength -= 10
<br>
        tickerdatalength -= 1
<br>
    currentpage -= 20
<br>

<br>
 with open('stockoverview.csv', 'wb') as csvfile:
<br>
    overview = csv.DictWriter(csvfile, delimiter=',', lineterminator='\n', fieldnames=titlesarray)
<br>
    overview.writeheader()
<br>

<br>
    for stock in alldata:
<br>
        overview.writerow({titlesarray[0] : stock[0], titlesarray[1] : stock[1],titlesarray[2] : stock[2],titlesarray[3] : stock[3],titlesarray[4] : stock[4], titlesarray[5] : stock[5], titlesarray[6] : stock[6], titlesarray[7] : stock[7] , titlesarray[8] : stock[8], titlesarray[9] : stock[9], titlesarray[10] : stock[10] })
<br>

<br>
 print "Finviz Overview Completed"
<br>
 return overview

        print( '{} price to book = {}'.format(symbol, pb_) )

        return pb_

class Quote(object):
<br>
  DATE_FMT = '%Y-%m-%d';  TIME_FMT = '%H:%M:%S'
<br>

<br>
  def __init__(self):
<br>
    self.symbol = '';    self.exchn=''
<br>
    self.date,self.time,self.open_,self.high,self.low,self.close,self.volume = ([] for _ in range(7))
<br>

<br>
  def append(self,dt,open_,high,low,close,volume):
<br>
    self.date.append(dt.date())
<br>
    self.time.append(dt.time())
<br>
    self.open_.append(float(open_))
<br>
    self.high.append(float(high))
<br>
    self.low.append(float(low))
<br>
    self.close.append(float(close))
<br>
    self.volume.append(int(volume))
<br>

<br>
  def to_csv(self):
<br>
    return ''.join(["{0},{1},{2},{3:.2f},{4:.2f},{5:.2f},{6:.2f},{7}\n".format(self.symbol,
<br>
              self.date[bar].strftime('%Y-%m-%d'),self.time[bar].strftime('%H:%M:%S'),
<br>
              self.open_[bar],self.high[bar],self.low[bar],self.close[bar],self.volume[bar])
<br>
              for bar in xrange(len(self.close))])
<br>

<br>
  def write_csv(self,filename):
<br>
    with open(filename,'w') as f:
<br>
      txt= self.to_csv()
<br>
      f.write(txt)
<br>

<br>
  def read_csv(self,filename):
<br>
    self.symbol = ''
<br>
    self.date,self.time,self.open_,self.high,self.low,self.close,self.volume = ([] for _ in range(7))
<br>
    for line in open(filename,'r'):
<br>
      symbol,ds,ts,open_,high,low,close,volume = line.rstrip().split(',')
<br>
      self.symbol = symbol
<br>
      dt = datetime.datetime.strptime(ds+' '+ts,self.DATE_FMT+' '+self.TIME_FMT)
<br>
      self.append(dt,open_,high,low,close,volume)
<br>
    return True
<br>

<br>
  def __repr__(self):
<br>
    return self.to_csv()
